commit_message:
Signature verification for cached images

This spec describes a change which would add
configurable functionality to verify signatures
associated with images stored in Nova's image
cache.

Change-Id: Ie0faa0b33475e24e72a9062231e0a501ccd51820
Blueprint: nova-support-image-signing
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/10/312210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Image Cache Verification ======================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-support-image-signing Nova currently does not support verification of signatures for images stored in Nova's image cache. Equipping Nova with the ability to verify image signatures for cached images will provide the end user with a strong cryptographic assurance that their image has not been modified while cached in Nova. This change will use the same data model for image metadata as the accompanying functionality in Glance, which allows the end user to sign images and verify these image signatures upon upload [1]. Problem description =================== Currently, Nova's integrity verification for cached images is limited to the verification of a SHA-1 hash. Since the hash is stored in the same filesystem as the cached disk image by default, this integrity check provides little protection in the case where a malicious user has access to the image cache. A malicious user may overwrite a cached image with an image containing malware, and then circumvent Nova's integrity checking mechanism by overwriting the disk image info file so that it contains a SHA-1 hash matching the corrupted image. Use Cases --------- * A user wants a high degree of assurance that an instance booted from Nova's image cache has not been corrupted or accidentally modified since Nova initially stored it in its image cache. With this proposed change, Nova may be configured to perform image signature verification on the images stored in its image cache. Proposed change =============== This change adds a 'verify_cache_signatures' config option to Nova. If this flag is set, Nova performs signature verification on cached images periodically, according to the period set by the existing 'checksum_interval_seconds' configuration option. To perform this verification, Nova retrieves the image ID from the info file for each image, uses the Glance API to retrieve the signature metadata associated with each image, and verifies this metadata using the existing signature_utils module. If the image fails this verification, Nova logs an error and then deletes the image from the image cache. Alternatives ------------ An alternative to signature-based image cache verification is to use the existing SHA-1 verification mechanism. This does not protect against the case where the attacker compromises the image cache, as previously stated. Additionally, the current functionality does not remove images from the cache when they fail validation; instead, it only logs a warning. Unless the admin is actively monitoring each compute node's logs and removing images from the cache as they fail validation, corrupted or tainted images can still be booted. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- This change will allow security-conscious cloud admins to configure their cloud to use stricter standards for the integrity of the image cache than what Nova can currently provide. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This feature will only be used if the verify_cache_signatures flag is set. When signature verification occurs there will be latency as a result of retrieving certificates from the key manager through the Castellan interface. There will also be CPU overhead associated with hashing the image data and decrypting a signature using a public key. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will need to set the verify_cache_signatures config flag and set an appropriate value for the checksum_interval_seconds in order to use this feature. If this feature is enabled, only signed images will be cached, since any unsigned image stored in the cache will fail validation and be removed during the first integrity check. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dane-fichter Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): None Work Items ---------- This change performs image cache verification in the following steps: * Retrieve the image's ID from the associated info file * Use the image's ID to retrieve the signature metadata from Glance * Use Nova's signature_utils module to verify the image's signature metadata * Log an error and delete the image from the cache if it fails signature verification Dependencies ============ This change depends on the signature_utils module, which is already included in Nova. Testing ======= Unit tests will be sufficient to test the functionality implemented in Nova. Documentation Impact ==================== Instructions for how to configure Nova to use this functionality will need to be documented. References ========== [1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/mitaka/implemented/image-signing-and-verification-support.html

commit_message:
Add image cache verification

This patch adds configurable functionality which
verifies Glance signatures associated with base
images stored in the libvirt driver's image cache.

Change-Id: I0c46874a71f8ddc64e64fe6225231dc9f5744c7f

This would allow using multinode jobs spawned by nodepool, but that is
not the only use case. Any cloud provider could be used by this setup,
including a 3rd party CI setup.

The scripts here are modified to support installing the undercloud
directly on the node running the toci_gate_test.sh script, which is
often the jenkins slave. This results in 1 less node (3 nodes total
instead of 4) to do the basic TripleO deployment.

The setup uses OpenVPN to create private networks among the nodes. This
is needed because you often can't route spoofed network traffic in a
public cloud (ip spoofing is disabled). OpenVPN offers an easy solution
to create and use private network subnets for deployment.

There is a new script named toci_instack_multinode.sh, to run the
multinode setup. Common parts of toci_instack.sh and
toci_instack_multinode.sh have been refactored into common_functions.sh
and common_vars.bash.

Change-Id: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758
Depends-On: I4ab1531f69c73457653f1cca3fe30cc32a04c129
Depends-On: I37330c6d068de4d9e717ec073fc3ddb758d65cb9

Depends-On: I1fdc62d61eb5d2ea7e9418e40aa8c07173169d35
"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2016-06-24 20:41:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/59ae4fec58f6ad6a98973b01f876c7a942288588', 'message': "Add mulitnode CI job support to tripleo-ci

This would allow using multinode jobs spawned by nodepool, but that is
not the only use case. Any cloud provider could be used by this setup,
including a 3rd party CI setup.

The scripts here are modified to support installing the undercloud
directly on the node running the toci_gate_test.sh script, which is
often the jenkins slave. This results in 1 less node (3 nodes total
instead of 4) to do the basic TripleO deployment.

The setup uses OpenVPN to create private networks among the nodes. This
is needed because you often can't route spoofed network traffic in a
public cloud (ip spoofing is disabled). OpenVPN offers an easy solution
to create and use private network subnets for deployment.

There is a new script named toci_instack_multinode.sh, to run the
multinode setup. Common parts of toci_instack.sh and
toci_instack_multinode.sh have been refactored into common_functions.sh
and common_vars.bash.

Change-Id: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758
Depends-On: I4ab1531f69c73457653f1cca3fe30cc32a04c129
Depends-On: I37330c6d068de4d9e717ec073fc3ddb758d65cb9
Depends-On: I1fdc62d61eb5d2ea7e9418e40aa8c07173169d35

The scripts here are modified to support installing the undercloud

multinode setup.

directly on the node running the toci_gate_test.sh script, which is
often the jenkins slave. When deploying an all in one Overcloud this
results in needing 2 nodes total to do the basic TripleO deployment.

There is a new script named toci_instack_multinode.sh, to run the
multinode setup.

Change-Id: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758
Depends-On: I4ab1531f69c73457653f1cca3fe30cc32a04c129

This would allow using multinode jobs spawned by nodepool, but that is
not the only use case. Any cloud provider could be used by this setup,
including a 3rd party CI setup.

The scripts here are modified to support installing the undercloud
directly on the node running the toci_gate_test.sh script, which is
often the jenkins slave. When deploying an all in one Overcloud this
results in needing 2 nodes total to do the basic TripleO deployment.

There is a new script named toci_instack_multinode.sh, to run the
multinode setup.

Change-Id: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758
Depends-On: I4ab1531f69c73457653f1cca3fe30cc32a04c129
Depends-On: Icd12a72a075f1f9b5d1978f16b36bb0b6a7d7a78

commit_message:
Add mulitnode CI job support to tripleo-ci

This would allow using multinode jobs spawned by nodepool, but that is
not the only use case. Any cloud provider could be used by this setup,
including a 3rd party CI setup.

The scripts here are modified to support installing the undercloud
directly on the node running the toci_gate_test.sh script, which is
often the jenkins slave. When deploying an all in one Overcloud this
results in needing 2 nodes total to do the basic TripleO deployment.

There is a new script named toci_instack_multinode.sh to run the
multinode setup.

Change-Id: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758

commit_message:
Share _get_random_uuid() among all tests

Currently, _get_random_uuid() is defined in test_coordination.py as a
staticmethod. This in turn forces multiple test suites to either use
that function from test_coordination (which was not done), or
re-implement the function on each call (which was done).

This patch proposes a move of the said function to tests/__init__.py,
which will allow every module to simply invoke
'tooz.tests.get_random_uuid()' if they wanted a random uuid. This will
eliminate a lot of code duplication in the test suite.

Change-Id: Idfc50d9da23790613d30bd87fb4da8eb272dce1f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/93/344793/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Delete gw port on exceptions

Clean up related core plugin ports on routers when there is a failure
creating the record for the router port.

The two partial bugs will be fixed after
I476d3e03c8ee763cc4be6d679fe9f501eb3a19b5 has merged.

Closes-Bug: #1600344
Partial-Bug: #1535225
Partial-Bug: #1535226
Change-Id: I8dd832f35e20d1ee090ebab921f0deea533b6fc8

subject: Add RouterPort binding to ha interface creation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-01 09:41:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6f07abdb4ca05b65a128bee0fb99818863b4c69e', 'message': 'Add RouterPort binding to l3 ha interfaces

The L3 HA interface cleanup routines during router deletion were
occuring after the parent router resource was deleted. This meant
that if they failed to delete, they would be orphaned since the
parent router was already gone.

This order of router delete and then HA delete was intentional
because deleting them before calling the parent router delete
function would cause them to be deleted before the checks to see
if the router was in use. If the router was in use, the HA interface
would be removed and would leave an HA router in an inconsitent state.
(See I956d0094ae6e2412e859d79feeb4003941d2bb4b for details)

This patch just has the L3 HA code add a RouterPort binding for the
HA interfaces. This allows the parent router_delete call to delete the
HA interfaces automatically after doing the in-use check but before
deleting the actual router.

In order to avoid a migration in a back-port, this is compatible with
previously created routers as well by continuing to call
_delete_ha_interfaces after the parent router is deleted. This means
that any routers created before this patch will potentially leave
orphans that will have to be manually deleted via the port API.

Closes-Bug: #1540271
Change-Id: Ifd3e007aaf2a2ed8123275aa3a9f540838e3c003
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-01 23:06:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/634238f8882b63d7711c00ddc3ab7299c2d1522c', 'message': 'Add RouterPort binding to l3 ha interfaces

The L3 HA interface cleanup routines during router deletion were
occuring after the parent router resource was deleted. This meant
that if they failed to delete, they would be orphaned since the
parent router was already gone.

This order of router delete and then HA delete was intentional
because deleting them before calling the parent router delete
function would cause them to be deleted before the checks to see
if the router was in use. If the router was in use, the HA interface
would be removed and would leave an HA router in an inconsitent state.
(See I956d0094ae6e2412e859d79feeb4003941d2bb4b for details)

This patch just has the L3 HA code add a RouterPort binding for the
HA interfaces. This allows the parent router_delete call to delete the
HA interfaces automatically after doing the in-use check but before
deleting the actual router.

In order to avoid a migration in a back-port, this is compatible with
previously created routers as well by continuing to call
_delete_ha_interfaces after the parent router is deleted. This means
that any routers created before this patch will potentially leave
orphans that will have to be manually deleted via the port API.

Closes-Bug: #1540271

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-01 23:09:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/dd52f8038b3aaf4a7f81c6144430b6f1e651275f', 'message': 'Add RouterPort binding to l3 ha interfaces

commit_message:
Add RouterPort binding to ha interface creation

The L3 HA interface cleanup routines during router deletion were
occuring after the parent router resource was deleted. This meant
that if they failed to delete, they would be orphaned since the
parent router was already gone.

This order of router delete and then HA delete was intentional
because deleting them before calling the parent router delete
function would cause them to be deleted before the checks to see
if the router was in use. If the router was in use, the HA interface
would be removed and would leave an HA router in an inconsitent state.
(See I956d0094ae6e2412e859d79feeb4003941d2bb4b for details)

This patch just has the L3 HA code add a RouterPort binding for the
HA interfaces. This allows the parent router_delete call to delete the
HA interfaces automatically after doing the in-use check but before
deleting the actual router.

In order to avoid a migration in a back-port, this is compatible with
previously created routers as well by continuing to call
_delete_ha_interfaces after the parent router is deleted. This means
that any routers created before this patch will potentially leave
orphans that will have to be manually deleted via the port API.

Closes-Bug: #1540271
Change-Id: Ifd3e007aaf2a2ed8123275aa3a9f540838e3c003
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/274571/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Change tunnel MTU calculation to support IPv6
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 12:40:46.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/install.rst', 'devstack/lib/networking-ovn'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/69d87d8d65c81dec6bfe248f5db061e8791d241c', 'message': "Change tunnel MTU calculation to support IPv6

The tunnel overhead calculation now accounts for the IP overhead.
See [1] for details. As a result, the networking OVN ML2 driver's
geneve max_header_size default configuration is 20 bytes too large
since it included the IPv4 overhead. This patch set takes advantage
of [1] and allows the IP overhead to be calculated by ML2.

Change-Id: Id8ac05c166ebd02e4abf94777020bde34cce808f
Related-Bug: #1584940
"}]
commit_message:
Change tunnel MTU calculation to support IPv6

The tunnel overhead calculation now accounts for the IP overhead.
See [1] for details. As a result, the networking OVN ML2 driver's
geneve max_header_size default configuration is 20 bytes too large
since it included the IPv4 overhead. This patch set takes advantage
of [1] and allows the IP overhead to be calculated by ML2.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320121

Change-Id: Id8ac05c166ebd02e4abf94777020bde34cce808f
Related-Bug: #1584940
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/04/344804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # GENEVE overlay protocol overhead. Defaults to 38 bytes plus the IP version # overhead (20 bytes for IPv4 (default) or 40 bytes for IPv6) which is determined # based on the ML2 overlay_ip_version option. The ML2 framework will use this to # configure the DHCP agent MTU option. OVN_GENEVE_OVERHEAD=${OVN_GENEVE_OVERHEAD:-38}
deleted_lines: # GENEVE overlay protocol overhead. Defaults to 58 bytes. The ML2 framework # will use this to configure the DHCP agent MTU option. # TODO(rtheis): This does not account for the 20 byte IPv6 MTU overhead. # This will need to be changed once https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320121/ # is fixed. OVN_GENEVE_OVERHEAD=${OVN_GENEVE_OVERHEAD:-58}

commit_message:
Make xenapi driver use flavor fields instead of legacy ones

This makes the xenapi driver use instance.flavor.root_gb instead
of the legacy instance.root_gb field (and friends).

The actual change here is very small, but a lot of xenapi tests
around this needed to be object-ified.

Change-Id: I6a45a22207a44e57506bc2171b10ba1df76277e0

commit_message:
Run ironic coverage jobs in the check pipeline as well

Nobody really pays attentions to post jobs, let's at least make sure
we don't break it. Also I find it pretty useful to see how coverage
is changed in a patch.

commit_message:
Support Networking-SFC Container

Networking-SFC is a neutron big-tent project
Kolla does not have Networking-SFC agent support for now. This
is essential for Service Function Chaining use case. Create
Networking-SFC container and run the agent if enabled.

Implements: blueprint enable-networking-sfc-support
Change-Id: Ib72b7746669eb015fc3ea5838c7f8fec3cc4bf4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/62/344762/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add hacking checks

Added required hacking checks to follow OpenStack coding
standards.

Change-Id: I20fe168f364296844a593ec3880e1639637dbf06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/14/342014/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =========================== - Step 1: Read the OpenStack Style Commandments http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/ - Step 2: Read on Masakari Specific Commandments ------------------------------ - [M301] no db session in public API methods (disabled) This enforces a guideline defined in ``oslo.db.sqlalchemy.session`` - [M302] timeutils.utcnow() wrapper must be used instead of direct calls to datetime.datetime.utcnow() to make it easy to override its return value in tests - [M303] capitalize help string Config parameter help strings should have a capitalized first letter - [M304] vim configuration should not be kept in source files. - [M305] Change assertTrue(isinstance(A, B)) by optimal assert like assertIsInstance(A, B). - [M306] Change assertEqual(type(A), B) by optimal assert like assertIsInstance(A, B) - [M307] Change assertEqual(A, None) or assertEqual(None, A) by optimal assert like assertIsNone(A) - [M308] Validate that debug level logs are not translated. - [M309] Don't import translation in tests - [M310] Setting CONF.* attributes directly in tests is forbidden. Use self.flags(option=value) instead. - [M311] Validate that LOG.info messages use _LI. - [M312] Validate that LOG.exception messages use _LE. - [M313] Validate that LOG.warning and LOG.warn messages use _LW. - [M314] Log messages require translations! - [M315] Method's default argument shouldn't be mutable - [M316] Ensure that the _() function is explicitly imported to ensure proper translations. - [M317] Ensure that jsonutils.%(fun)s must be used instead of json.%(fun)s - [M318] Change assertTrue/False(A in/not in B, message) to the more specific assertIn/NotIn(A, B, message) - [M319] Check for usage of deprecated assertRaisesRegexp - [M320] Must use a dict comprehension instead of a dict constructor with a sequence of key-value pairs. - [M321] Change assertEqual(A in B, True), assertEqual(True, A in B), assertEqual(A in B, False) or assertEqual(False, A in B) to the more specific assertIn/NotIn(A, B) - [M322] Check masakari.utils.spawn() is used instead of greenthread.spawn() and eventlet.spawn() - [M323] contextlib.nested is deprecated - [M324] Config options should be in the central location ``masakari/conf/`` - [M325] Check for common double word typos - [M326] Python 3: do not use dict.iteritems. - [M327] Python 3: do not use dict.iterkeys. - [M328] Python 3: do not use dict.itervalues. - [M329] Deprecated library function os.popen()

commit_message:
Add missing install_tempest_plugins call to upgrade-tempest

Without this call the new installation will not run plugin-specific tests.
The call is placed after configure_tempest just like it's done in tempest
devstack code.

Change-Id: Ia2a5b9cc535c7c46728eee6284a36340745e9043

commit_message:
Add async param to local conductor live_migrate_instance

A new async param was added to the RPC version of live_migrate_instance
in the conductor but it was missed on the local conductor API. This adds
that parameter and adds a unit test that uses the parameter.

Change-Id: I7c44a8fc72ba9afbb67269b0bc7ad59eb9b1580e
Closes-Bug: #1604475

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary overrides of service variables

The heat service user, project, region, and password are the same
regardless of the heat service endpoints.

Use the existing heat namespaced variables instead of overriding and
providing a generic 'service_' variable for use with the service setup
tasks.

This also fixes a recursive loop issue seen when deploying the
integrated release with Ansible 2.1.

Change-Id: I350def02e04cd6d8279dcccade607ca3543ef4fa

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary overrides of service variables

The cinder service user, project, region, and password are the same
regardless of the API endpoint version.

Use the existing cinder namespaced variables instead of overriding and
providing a generic 'service_' variable for use with the service setup
tasks.

This also fixes a recursive loop issue seen when deploying the
integrated release with Ansible 2.1: http://tinyurl.com/hhuljtu

Change-Id: I469dcabb03c792abbad7f65a17bfa5f7146dcfa7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder refs/changes/56/322256/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add functional test hook for fwaas command

This patch adds a hook into functional test so that
fwaas command test runs.

(cherry picked from commit 6bc4685f6b50fb8883c67b7f80b12ced6228d27b)
Change-Id: Ib4ba644b22db0df91a9b0c7011b46ece337198af

commit_message:
Replace while with if in resolve function

Functions can't return functions, so we don't need to use `while`.
This doesn't change behaviour of code, just makes it more understandable
and convenient.

Change-Id: Ia1dac5a9583cb99db23a8838412e5bc02e93ef4c

commit_message:
Replace deprecated LOG.warn with LOG.warning

LOG.warn is deprecated. It is still used in few modules.
Replaced with non-deprecated LOG.warning.

commit_message:
[DOC] Added docs for sahara+ironic

Added instructions "How to a run a Sahara cluster on Ironic"

Change-Id: I888269a221b56cb8f8aab75b7556e965071c3d2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/60/339560/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: How do run a Sahara cluster on bare metal servers ================================================= Hadoop clusters are designed to store and analyze extremely large amounts of unstructured data in distributed computing environments. Sahara enables you to boot Hadoop clusters in both virtual and bare metal environments. When Booting Hadoop clusters with Sahara on bare metal servers, you benefit from the bare metal performance with self-service resource provisioning. To a run a Sahara cluster on Ironic ----------------------------------- 1. Create a new OpenStack environment using Devstack as described in the `Devstack Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/devstack/>`_ 2. Install Ironic as described in the `Ironic Installation Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/deploy/install-guide.html>`_ 3. Install Sahara as described in the `Sahara Installation Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/sahara/userdoc/installation.guide.html>`_ 4. Build the Sahara image and prepare it for uploading to Glance: - Build an image for Sahara plugin with the ``-b`` flag. Use sahara image elements when building the image. See `<https://github.com/openstack/sahara-image-elements>`_ - Convert the qcow2 image format to the raw format. For example: .. sourcecode:: console $ qemu-img convert -O raw image-converted.qcow image-converted-from-qcow2.raw .. - Mount the raw image to the system. - ``chroot`` to the mounted directory and remove the installed grub. - Build grub2 from sources and install to ``/usr/sbin``. - In ``/etc/sysconfig/selinux``, disable selinux ``SELINUX=disabled`` - In the configuration file, set ``onboot=yes`` and ``BOOTPROTO=dhcp`` for every interface. - Add the configuration files for all interfaces in the ``/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts`` directory. 5. Upload the Sahara disk image to Glance, and register it in the Sahara Image Registry. Referencing its separate kernel and initramfs images. 6. Configure the bare metal network for the Sahara cluster nodes: - Add bare metal servers to your environment manually referencing their IPMI addresses (Ironic does not detect servers), for Ironic to manage the servers power and network. For example: .. code-block:: bash $ ironic node-create -d pxe_ipmitool \ $ -i ipmi_address=$IP_ADDRESS \ $ -i ipmi_username=$USERNAME \ $ -i ipmi_password=$PASSWORD \ $ -i pxe_deploy_kernel=$deploy.kernel.id \ $ -i pxe_deploy_ramdisk=$deploy.ramfs.id $ ironic port-create -n $NODE_ID -a "$MAC_eth1" .. - Add the hardware information: .. code-block:: bash $ ironic node-update $NODE_ID add properties/cpus=$CPU \ $ properties/memory_mb=$RAM properties/local_gb=$ROOT_GB \ $ properties/cpu_arch='x86_64' .. 7. Add a special flavor for the bare metal instances with an arch meta parameter to match the virtual architecture of the servers CPU with the metal one. For example: .. code-block:: bash $ nova flavor-create baremetal auto $RAM $DISK_GB $CPU $ nova flavor-key baremetal set cpu_arch=x86_64 .. Note: +++++ The vCPU ad vRAM parameters (x86_64 in the example) will not be applied because the operating system has access to the real CPU cores and RAM. Only the root disk parameter is applied, and Ironic will resize the root disk partition. Ironic supports only a flat network topology for the bare metal provisioning, you must use Neutron to configure it. 8. Launch your Sahara cluster on Ironic from the cluster template: * Log in to Horizon. * Go to Data Processing > Node Group Templates. * Find the templates that belong to the plugin you would like to use * Update those templates to use bare metal flavor instead of the default one * Go to Data Processing > Cluster Templates. * Click Launch Cluster. * On the Launch Cluster dialog: * Specify the bare metal network for cluster nodes The cluster provisioning time is slower compared to the cluster provisioning of the same size that runs on VMs. Ironic does real hardware reports which is time consuming, and the whole root disk is filled from ``/dev/zero`` for security reasons. Known limitations: ================== * Security groups are not applied. * When booting a nova instance with a bare metal flavor, the user can not provide a pre-created neutron port to ``nova boot`` command. `LP1544195 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1544195>`_ * Nodes are not isolated by tenants. * VM to Bare Metal network routing is not allowed. * The user has to specify the count of ironic nodes before Fuel deploys an environment. * The user cannot use the same image for several ironic node types. For example, if there are 3 ironic node types, the user has to create 3 images and 3 flavors. * Multiple interfaces on a single node are not supported. Fuel configures only one interface.

Add reno notes about http_proxy_to_wsgi middleware

This note is meant for Id33a0f7eeb8ced77d09f9edd6b1d65697d8bcfe7

added_lines: --- security: - http_proxy_to_wsgi is taken into use instead of the deprecated ssl middleware. This makes it easier for deployers to have Manila running behind a proxy that terminates TLS connections. This middleware addition adds the enable_proxy_headers_parsing option to the oslo_middleware section which needs to be set in the configuration file in order to enable middleware to do its work.

The network_device_mtu option will be removed from Neutron in Newton.
The global_physnet_mtu option was introduced in Mitaka. Before Mitaka,

commit_message:
Configure infrastructure MTU with global_physnet_mtu

The network_device_mtu option will be removed from Neutron in Newton.
The global_physnet_mtu option was introduced in Mitaka. Before Mitaka,
Neutron did not have any multinode jobs that would require setting the
infrastructure MTU for inter-node connectivity.

Change-Id: I337b284076a794027fbd63796119d56bd1923cf2
Related-Bug: #1603493
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/75/342975/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
echo -e "[[post-config|\$NEUTRON_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
global_physnet_mtu=$EXTERNAL_BRIDGE_MTU" >> local.conf echo -e "[[post-config|\$NEUTRON_CONF]]
[DEFAULT]
global_physnet_mtu=$EXTERNAL_BRIDGE_MTU" >> local.conf

commit_message:
sleep before waiting requests

to avoid issue with fast completing requests we need
to sleep a little before actual waiting for requests.

Closes-bug: 1596553
Change-Id: I17993f091241243eea670c7cf591ddd9c23d069c
(cherry picked from commit ef00d9463524fe9e0b6935474cdd7b46fd4da1bb)

commit_message:
Ensure test_cleanup_stale_devices fails gracefully

Give some time for devices to be cleared before we claim defeat.

Change-Id: I34b2ec634f1c9ec27a1b82cc3f55a5e0b7d71237
Closes-bug: #1604115

commit_message:
[DOC] Inform operators about limited quotas

Added information about limited default security group rules
quotas and how operator can fix it.

Change-Id: Id06641cd9e433119c9740eaf41e6ea3e44a22cdf
closes-bug: 1543157
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/45/337245/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Known issues ------------ When auto_security_group is used, the amount of created security group rules is bigger than the default values configured in neutron.conf. So the default limit should be raised up to some bigger value. You can change it in neutron.conf file: .. sourcecode:: cfg [quotas] quota_security_group = 1000 quota_security_group_rule = 10000 Or you can execute openstack CLI command: .. sourcecode:: console openstack quota set --secgroups 1000 --secgroup-rules 10000 $PROJECT_ID

commit_message:
Add support for static actions API

StaticActionManager is added to use static actions API.
Corresponding tools are added to Murano CLI and OpenStackClient.

Depends-on: I17ab2eba0fd6c42309667f42d0644d21940ab02d
Change-Id: Ib6a60f8e33c5d3593a55db9f758e94e27f0a4445
Partially-implements: blueprint static-actions

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # Not a true manager yet; should be changed to be one if CRUD # functionality becomes available for actions. from concurrent import futures class StaticActionManager(object): def __init__(self, api): self.api = api def call(self, arguments): url = '/v1/actions' executor = futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=1) return executor.submit(self.api.json_request, url, 'POST', data=arguments) def get_result(self, future): if future.running(): return "Result in not available yet" else: resp, body = future.result() return body or None

Add Python 3.5 classifier

Since the Python 3.5 gate job builds cleanly now, we should claim
support for Python 3.5 in the metadata's classifier.

Change-Id: I215313560d6bb3501093c95870c12cde1f11b5a5

The gate jobs now support Python 3.5 and plan to phase out 3.4.
This patch adds the Python 3.5 classifier, py35 to the default
tox environment, and fixes a py35 only issue.

In 3.5, the ast module returns the correct value for the col_offset
of a function definition whereas earlier versions did not.

commit_message:
Handle Py35 fix of ast.node.col_offset bug

In 3.5, the ast module returns the correct value for the col_offset
of a function definition whereas earlier versions did not. The value
is off by one column.

Closes-Bug: #1603236

Change-Id: I7835d7ed8d652a6bd585e8e0372fab402424038d

commit_message:
Prepare for changes in python-muranoclient action call

Due to changes in commit I672ff44a547b318a3b8cd5b73882a3e1b956d915
call of action will return ActionResult object instead of string with
task_id. This patch allows dashboard to work with both types of returned
values and thus makes change to client possible.
After client changes we can leave just the new variant.

Change-Id: I7e545006f7f6cdd4217e7d8e04e1841d3fee5c07
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/39/340239/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: result = mc.actions.call(environment_id, action_id) if hasattr(result, 'get_task_id'): result = result.get_task_id() return result

commit_message:
Make ActionManager and StaticActionManager consistent

In the new StaticActionManager, call() method returns special
StaticActionResult object with methods check_result() and
get_result(). This patch makes ActionManager behaviour similar -
its call() method returns ActionResult object with the same
interface. ActionManager and StaticActionManager now are
inheritors of AsyncActionManager class that defines the interface.
To maintain backward compatibility ActionResult also
has get_task_id() method, and ActionResult can also be provided
to get_method() as an argument instead of task_id.

Depends-on: I7e545006f7f6cdd4217e7d8e04e1841d3fee5c07
Change-Id: I672ff44a547b318a3b8cd5b73882a3e1b956d915

commit_message:
Allow to enroll nodes with oneview driver

This patch allows import nodes with *_oneview drivers from
space separated nodes file.

Change-Id: I6d8447fd0404f9746bbfb0e38bf3c6c66b7ab1f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/51/328451/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # *_oneview: # <Server Hardware URI> <Server Hardware Type URI> <Enclosure Group URI> <Server Profile Template URI> ## ``pxe_iscsi_cimc``, ``pxe_agent_cimc``, ``pxe_ucs``, ``pxe_cimc`` and ``*_pxe_oneview``function is_deployed_by_oneview { [[ -z "${IRONIC_DEPLOY_DRIVER##*_oneview}" ]] && return 0 return 1 } elif is_deployed_by_oneview; then local server_hardware_uri server_hardware_uri=$(echo $hardware_info |awk '{print $1}') local server_hardware_type_uri server_hardware_type_uri=$(echo $hardware_info |awk '{print $2}') local enclosure_group_uri enclosure_group_uri=$(echo $hardware_info |awk '{print $3}') local server_profile_template_uri server_profile_template_uri=$(echo $hardware_info |awk '{print $4}') node_options+=" -i server_hardware_uri=$server_hardware_uri\ -i server_hardware_type_uri=$server_hardware_type_uri\ -i enclosure_group_uri=$enclosure_group_uri\ -i server_profile_template_uri=$server_profile_template_uri"

commit_message:
Implement rbac list and show command

1. implement "openstack network rbac list"
2. implement "openstack network rbac show"
3. also add FakeRBACPolicy to test "network rbac xxx" command
The unit test class similar to FakeRouter, which is able to
fake one or more rbac policies. It will be used by the rbac
CRUD patches.

Change-Id: I6c97bc8819698546895fd530464a2cbb347bf77d
Co-Authored-By: Huanxuan Ao <huanxuan.ao@easystack.cn>
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-client-rbac
Depends-On: I88f409a24947b67146c0f93ec8480834cef56d2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/22/319522/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class FakeRBACPolicies(object): """Fake one or more routers.""" @staticmethod def create_one_rbac_policies(attrs=None): """Create a fake rbac policy :param Dictionary attrs: A dictionary with all attributes :return: A FakeResource object, with id, action, target_tenant, tenant_id, type """ attrs = attrs or {} # Set default attributes rbac_attrs = { 'id': 'rbac-id-' + uuid.uuid4().hex, 'object_type': 'network', 'object_id': 'net-id-' + uuid.uuid4().hex, 'action': 'access_as_shared', 'target_tenant': 'target-tenant-' + uuid.uuid4().hex, 'tenant_id': 'tenant-id-' + uuid.uuid4().hex, } rbac_attrs.update(attrs) rbac = fakes.FakeResource(info=copy.deepcopy(rbac_attrs), loaded=True) # Set attributes with special mapping in OpenStack SDK. rbac.project_id = rbac_attrs['tenant_id'] return rbac @staticmethod def create_rbac_polices(attrs=None, count=2): """Create multiple fake rbac policies. :param Dictionary attrs: A dictionary with all attributes :param int count: The number of routers to fake :return: A list of FakeResource objects faking the rbac policies """ rbac_policies = [] for i in range(0, count): rbac_policies.append(FakeRouter.create_one_router(attrs)) return rbac_policies @staticmethod def get_rbac_policies(rbac_policies=None, count=2): """Get an iterable MagicMock object with a list of faked rbac policies. If rbac policies list is provided, then initialize the Mock object with the list. Otherwise create one. :param List routers: A list of FakeResource objects faking rbac policies :param int count: The number of routers to fake :return: An iterable Mock object with side_effect set to a list of faked rbac policies """ if rbac_policies is None: rbac_policies = FakeRouter.create_routers(count) return mock.MagicMock(side_effect=rbac_policies)

"ip fixed add/remove" to "server add/remove fixed ip":

  to "--source <network-or-pool>" option so that Neutron and Nova 
  networks could share the same option.
* Add new command "floating ip create/delete/list/show", and doc.
* Deprecate "ip floating create/delete/list/show" command.

commit_message:
Transfer "ip floating CRUD" to "floating ip CRUD"

This patch does the following things to transfer
"ip floating xxx" to "floating ip xxx":
* Add new command "floating ip create/delete/list/show", and doc.
* Deprecate "ip floating create/delete/list/show" command.

Change-Id: Ib071acaac81988431244e858bddafa7f93403df5
Implements: blueprint rework-ip-commands
Closes-bug: 1555990
Co-Authored-By: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>

subject: Resolves issue where to allow custom repo URLS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 13:34:02.000000000', 'files': ['sahara/plugins/ambari/deploy.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/80a00cd9a5e5b243261d58d5aa23a8ba69386aa8', 'message': 'Resolves issue where to allow custom repo URLS

Using an centos7 image and changing the HDP and HDP-UTILS URL location
resulted in an error of
"os_type=os_type_map[client.get_host_info[ambari.fqdn())["os_type"]]
KeyError: u'centos7'. This results in only being able to change the
HDP and HDP-UTILS URL if you were using centos6 or redhat6.This change
adds centos7 and redhat7 to the map to allow custom HDP and HDP-UTILS URLs.

Should we add additional operating systems to the list?

Closes-Bug: #1599252

Change-Id: Iaa5cd773c5daeabeda287048a2d3f8696faa1436
(cherry picked from commit d067680e68f97b47665bbd9ece2dd810c254385a)
'}]
commit_message:
Resolves issue where to allow custom repo URLS

Using an centos7 image and changing the HDP and HDP-UTILS URL location
resulted in an error of
"os_type=os_type_map[client.get_host_info[ambari.fqdn())["os_type"]]
KeyError: u'centos7'. This results in only being able to change the
HDP and HDP-UTILS URL if you were using centos6 or redhat6.This change
adds centos7 and redhat7 to the map to allow custom HDP and HDP-UTILS URLs.

Should we add additional operating systems to the list?

Closes-Bug: #1599252

Change-Id: Iaa5cd773c5daeabeda287048a2d3f8696faa1436
(cherry picked from commit d067680e68f97b47665bbd9ece2dd810c254385a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/40/344840/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "redhat6": "redhat6", "centos7": "redhat7", "redhat7": "redhat7"

subject: Disable security group tests in tempest-dsvm-cells-rc using a config option
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-21 20:30:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/98aaf9f58089d8aa58a1cd6bbf55aa21646fc24a', 'message': "WIP: Disable security group tests in tempest-dsvm-cells-rc using a config option

Currently, the tempest security group tests for tempest-dsvm-cells-rc
are blocked becausecells doesn't support security groups.  The block is
now done using a nova blacklist:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/devstack/tempest-dsvm-cells-rc.
Change to block the tests based on a new tempest config option -
compute-feature-enabled.security_groups.

Also, some of the tempest scenario tests attempt to create a server with a
security group.  These will not work with cells, so use the new config option
to block those tests.

This commit changes tempest-dsvm-cells-rc to remove blacklisted tests
that are now blocked by the config option.

commit_message:
Disable security group tests in tempest-dsvm-cells-rc using a config option

Currently, the tempest security group tests for tempest-dsvm-cells-rc
are blocked because cells doesn't support security groups.  The block is
now done using a nova blacklist:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/devstack/tempest-dsvm-cells-rc

This commit changes tempest-dsvm-cells-rc to remove blacklisted tests.
Inclusion of security group related tests is now controlled
by the tempest config option compute-feature-enabled.security_groups.

Change-Id: Icb6d9934dfbe4a4f03e38a47fb9d29a0e72d1942
Partial-Bug: 1495653
Depends-On: I4f74b80024a9bcc374d374d86052dceb40598d32

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 15:56:13.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/compute/servers/test_attach_interfaces.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/7f85952ce3dcc8e6e8064dc70abeb80ad148fc2f', 'message': 'Fix Reassign Port Test

Change-Id: I6aff802f6e404494af90536d7b60e696de26df37

commit_message:
Fix Reassign Port Test

This test was deleting the server before trying to add the an
interface to the server. Moved the server cleanup to the end of
the test.

Change-Id: I6aff802f6e404494af90536d7b60e696de26df37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/00/344900/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # add our cleanups for the servers since we bypassed the base class for server in servers: self.addCleanup(waiters.wait_for_server_termination, self.servers_client, server['id']) self.addCleanup(self.servers_client.delete_server, server['id'])
deleted_lines: # add our cleanups for the servers since we bypassed the base class for server in servers: self.addCleanup(waiters.wait_for_server_termination, self.servers_client, server['id']) self.addCleanup(self.servers_client.delete_server, server['id'])

commit_message:
PCI-DSS Adds password_expires_at to API specs

This patch adds a new user response attribute, password_expires_at,
to the Identity API v3 specs.

Passord expires validation implementation:
https://review.openstack.org/333360

Partially-implements: blueprint pci-dss

Change-Id: I07c10de627898d6ac79578dc24292ded4a2190f1

commit_message:
Add python-neutronclient to osc-plugin-jobs

Neutron is transitioning its CLI to OSC. Some CLIs will reside
within python-openstackclient while others will be OSC plugins
within python-neutronclient (see [1]). In order to support this,
add osc-plugin-jobs support for python-neutronclient per [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/309587/
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/plugins.html

Change-Id: I86595e02ec23f2ab68964ba2bdab51ccb3ffef8a
Related-Bug: #1521291

commit_message:
Update dist-sort module for better effectiveness

The dist-sort module has been updated to ensure its execution
is effective, fast, and nonintrusive. There are cases where
the rounds made by the module take an excessive amount of time
to complete. This change ensures that the module is limiting its
rounds to a known index and the iterable is processed using a
generator.

Change-Id: I03d1f70cb6cd17f38ef37b4d8371a8982beca29e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add functional tests for devstack gate

This patch adds 'functional' test that will be run by dsvm gate.
A 'cloudsConfig.js' file converts OpenStack environment variables
into a configuration object similar to 'clouds.yaml' structure, so
tests can communicate with devstack.
Karma activates a babel plugin in order to convert those environment
variables into inline values.

A dummy test has been added to demonstrate use of devstack config.

This review was inspired from 'python-openstacksdk' work:
https://github.com/openstack/python-openstacksdk

Change-Id: I6a685337ce5e057c5df112a83895b4c9c4691f6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/48/339748/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import Test from "../../src/index.js"; describe("Simple functional test", function () { it("should call keystone URL", function (done) { var testKeystone = function(response) { expect(response.status).toBe(200); done(); }; var failTest = function(error) { expect(error).toBeUndefined(); done(); }; var t = new Test(); t.getExample(process.env.OS_AUTH_URL) .then(testKeystone) .catch(failTest); }); });

commit_message:
Fix unit tests

Unit tests fail because of two reasons:
1) Latest manilaclient requires more stricter mocking in unit tests.
So, mock it properly.
2) Horizon's test settings file has not been used. So, start using
original Horizon's settings file instead of our own obsolete version.

Change-Id: If83e66d4b2f0f1db181e7c23ac256c498566c2da
Closes-Bug: #1604348

subject: Use own rpm_split_filename function to reduce dependencies
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-14 08:24:36.000000000', 'files': ['tools/rpm-packaging-status.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging-tools/commit/9cffd46bcafc86e41600853d340463cdc08aa92a', 'message': "Use own rpm_split_filename function to reduce dependencies

rpmUtils is from yum but we just need a single function to
split a rpm filename into it's components.
So copy the function from rpmUtils and use the copy.

Change-Id: I4c0826aebaee9e65ae852d0d1e0e88341053dc4b
"}]
commit_message:
Use own rpm_split_filename function to reduce dependencies

rpmUtils is from yum but we just need a single function to
split a rpm filename into it's components.
So copy the function from rpmUtils and use the copy.

Change-Id: I4c0826aebaee9e65ae852d0d1e0e88341053dc4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging-tools refs/changes/39/342039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _rpm_split_filename(filename): """Taken from yum's rpmUtils.miscutils.py file Pass in a standard style rpm fullname Return a name, version, release, epoch, arch, e.g.:: foo-1.0-1.i386.rpm returns foo, 1.0, 1, i386 1:bar-9-123a.ia64.rpm returns bar, 9, 123a, 1, ia64 """ if filename[-4:] == '.rpm': filename = filename[:-4] archIndex = filename.rfind('.') arch = filename[archIndex+1:] relIndex = filename[:archIndex].rfind('-') rel = filename[relIndex+1:archIndex] verIndex = filename[:relIndex].rfind('-') ver = filename[verIndex+1:relIndex] epochIndex = filename.find(':') if epochIndex == -1: epoch = '' else: epoch = filename[:epochIndex] name = filename[epochIndex + 1:verIndex] return name, ver, rel, epoch, arch (name, ver, release, epoch, arch) = _rpm_split_filename(
deleted_lines: from rpmUtils.miscutils import splitFilename (name, ver, release, epoch, arch) = splitFilename(

commit_message:
Add uplink provider network to neutron network

At midonet we are using a custom provider network
type since edge router is also inside our managed
topology

commit_message:
Add region_name into neutron-client for libvirt

Passing in the region_name argument for creating neutron client
is required same as nova client. Parameter region_name is required
for libvirt detection plugin so that neutron knows which endpoint
from the service catalog to choose.

This only occurs on multi region deployments.

Change-Id: I9509292bfaf319e80f5cfe08a4321ca635ce3403

commit_message:
Change names of token drivers in init.pp

Documentation for Keystone initialization refers to UPPER or
CamelCase names. Keystone drivers use all lowercase, and using
an incorrectly cased name will throw a Stevedore load error.

Change-Id: I50aa7da46018799224031226d23fa45820b51a20

commit_message:
Add rabbitmq service check

* Check whether rabbitmq is online before doing any rabbitmq queries
* Add new provider for custom service checks

Change-Id: I1fb27ab2d731dc3fa7daa3694c9da3a01f318695
Closes-Bug: 1591213
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/34/333334/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Port nova test_serversV21.Base64ValidationTest to Python 3

Remove unused method in ServersController and corresponding test cases:
- api/openstack/compute/servers.py
  ServersController._decode_base64
- api/openstack/compute/test_serversV21.py
  Base64ValidationTest

Partially implements: blueprint nova-python3-newton

Change-Id: If7379db5abf686dd8db6ec1d0950637552913505
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/23/342723/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import oslo_serialization return oslo_serialization.base64.decode_as_text(data) except UnicodeDecodeError: return oslo_serialization.base64.decode_as_bytes(data)

commit_message:
ExecutionDriver handles exec requests from replicated PEs

agnostic.py:Dse2Runtime now requests exec through request_execute,
ExecutionDriver locally selects and obeys leader PE-node.
Leadership is vacated when heartbeat is lost.

tests/helper.py:TestFailureException defined to allow using
assertRaises to check for test failure when retry tests fails
(generic Exception disallowed by pep8 check/gate)

Closes-Bug: 1600012
Partially implements blueprint: high-availability-design

Change-Id: I32b6d8a8d78bfac74b85d2b415035083b2917fb8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/65/339965/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time # TODO(dse2)(HA): remove this when DSE1 support is ended def request_execute(self, context, action, action_args): return self.service.request_execute(context, action, action_args) self.LEADER_CHECK_INTERVAL = 3 self.LEADER_TIMEOUT = 5 self._leader_node_id = None # FIXME(ekcs): should stop running if the DataService is "stopped". # but it's not clear how to do it without inheriting from # DataSourceDriver, overriding start()/stop(), and running into # multiple inheritance issues eventlet.spawn(self._check_leader_heartbeat_loop) def _check_leader_heartbeat_loop(self): while 1: if self._leader_node_id is not None: peers = self.node.dse_status()['peers'] if (self._leader_node_id not in peers or time.time() - peers[self._leader_node_id]['last_hb_time'] > self.LEADER_TIMEOUT): self._leader_node_id = None eventlet.sleep(self.LEADER_CHECK_INTERVAL) def request_execute(self, context, action, action_args): """Accept execution requests and execute requests from leader""" node_id = context.get('node_id', None) if node_id is not None: if self._leader_node_id is None: self._leader_node_id = node_id self.execute(action, action_args) if self._leader_node_id == node_id: self.execute(action, action_args)

commit_message:
Fix share_helpers default value.

Manila commit 401c8d982e8b6a95f01784cf647a7ac16513d61a moved the share helpers
into a separate module and changed the name of the CIFSHelper. This
change set updates the defaults used by puppet to match the new helper
module names.

Change-Id: I66b73858512ee5aed416aae840946f26c4cdc223

commit_message:
Add ansible "free" strategy to plays

This change adds the "free" strategy to playbook execution where it
makes sense. This should speed up playbook execution time.

Change-Id: I7412f8708e5356d1d46a06ce7b3ab076ff5aee03
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/45/344845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added *.tgz to .gitignore files

`npm pack` creates a tarball, which is not ignored by gitignore and
thus causes the assert-no-extra-files job to error (silently). This
adds these files to the .gitignore.

Change-Id: Ia1360973acabdec347e9ca449eb9c17d8e416860

commit_message:
Fix cfapi test job

After change I17ab2eba0fd6c42309667f42d0644d21940ab02d was merged cfapi
job starts failing. This cause of it is the change in mock_muranopl.yaml
file which is used in tempest tests. Now we remove this change and
update mechanism which added class name by overwrite mock_muranopl.yaml.

Related-Bug: #1604050
Change-Id: I9ab62cd60b25e39f9ec90a85dfa25c80fc3adbad

commit_message:
Use bundletester for amulet test execution

Switch to using bundletester for execution of functional tests,
leveraging tox to build out test virtualenvs.

Rename amulet tests inline with gate-* and dfs-* naming standards.

Update README to refer to functional testing section of the charm
guide.

Change-Id: I038797ce2ac891567707e1b9c0697ba31ba3baed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-swift-storage refs/changes/15/344115/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:func27-noop] # DRY RUN - For Debug basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" -n --no-destroy [testenv:func27] # Charm Functional Test # Run all gate tests which are +x (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-smoke] # Charm Functional Test # Run a specific test as an Amulet smoke test (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json gate-basic-xenial-mitaka --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dfs] # Charm Functional Test # Run all deploy-from-source tests which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dfs-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dev] # Charm Functional Test # Run all development test targets which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dev-*" --no-destroy

commit_message:
Move unit tests to `unit` directory

This patch moves tests to a new `unit` directory for clarity. For
devstackgate we will need functional tests. Those will be placed in
a `functional` directory.

Change-Id: Id703ae1b9e7c448290af709e3e55d52ac2857a75
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/js-openstack-lib refs/changes/79/339679/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: var srcContext = require.context('../../src/', true, /\.js$/);

subject: Remove deprecated code
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-28 16:12:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/727166cc83604bbc5464875c6b47ad13849d2d98', 'message': 'Remove deprecated code

Dropped:
* classes -  "keystone::python"
* parameters - in "keystone" class:
  * admin_workers
  * public_workers
  * service_provider
  * validate_service
  * validate_insecure
  * validate_cacert
  * validate_auth_url

Behavior changes:
* "keystone" class:
  * "cache_memcache_servers" parameter:
    * don't inherit "memcache_servers"
    * "memcache_servers" & "cache_memcache_servers"
      defaults coincide
    * but it is expected to use both params
  * run keystone under Apache (as a web
    service)
* "keystone::resource::service_identity" type:
  * forbid keystone endpoint defenition
    with unset "service_type"

Notes:
* "cache_enabled" ("keystone" class):
  * remove legacy automatic enabling

commit_message:
Remove deprecated code

Dropped:
* classes -  "keystone::python"
* parameters - in "keystone" class:
  * admin_workers
  * public_workers

Behavior changes:
* "keystone" class:
  * "cache_memcache_servers" parameter:
    * don't inherit "memcache_servers"
    * "memcache_servers" & "cache_memcache_servers"
      defaults coincide
    * but it is expected to use both params
    service)

Notes:
* "cache_enabled" ("keystone" class):
  * remove legacy automatic enabling
  * enabled by default (os_service_default)

Co-Authored-By: Iury Gregory <iurygregory@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I1316dd95074f1d296210dd87504938d83ee476d6

commit_message:
Fix keystone_authtoken middleware for nova

This change removes the signing_dir from the nova configuration as it is
for PKI tokens which are no longer supported. Additionally, the
keystone_authtoken/memcached_servers should be configured only for the
api services.

Change-Id: I35b91b4fe65d79a5cd4ed81a584d67a97a1e21d5
Related-Bug: #1600276

commit_message:
Allow a grace period when cancelling a stack update

Use a progress callback for cancelling updates so that we will apply the
usual grace period to allow resources to complete when cancelling a stack
update, instead of cancelling immediately. Previously, resources could
unneccessarily be marked as FAILED, resulting in them unneccessarily being
replaced on a subsequent update.

Change-Id: I0a5bf998be764e4d6d4c6ea86aaca7f715b93d06
Related-Bug: #1591337

commit_message:
Use a queue instead of an event to send messages

This has a couple of effects. One is that we can send more than one message
to an action (since the action need not terminate immediately upon
receiving a message). The other is that we only ever receive the message
once, instead of every time we check for it once it has been sent.

Change-Id: Ib3b33534c0e8b03dfbbb1acde6f7b2d3dcfa82b6

subject: Raise the last exception thrown into DependencyTaskGroup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-22 18:41:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/bfa592ee1f28ca0625fd379381fd23d4fea06c83', 'message': 'Raise the last exception thrown into DependencyTaskGroup

Normally when exceptions are caught in DependencyTaskGroup, we cancel with
a grace period and then re-raise the first exception once all subtasks are
stopped. This means that e.g. when a resource fails, the exception the
stack gets back is from the first resource failure and not e.g. any
resulting exceptions from cancelled in-progress resources.

However, for exceptions thrown in to the task from the outside (as opposed
to raised by one of the subtasks), we generally want the *last* one to be
re-raised. Specifically, if a cancel-without-rollback exception is thrown
followed by a cancel-with-rollback, we want the with-rollback exception to
be re-raised so that the stack knows to roll back.

Change-Id: I4843f9a55a4897a7af86a9aa69df073913fd03e6
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-13 21:45:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/5666a5b92d134cdcc9a25db86d2f574f31845cca', 'message': 'Raise the last exception thrown into DependencyTaskGroup

Normally when exceptions are caught in DependencyTaskGroup, we cancel with
a grace period and then re-raise the first exception once all subtasks are
stopped. This means that e.g. when a resource fails, the exception the
stack gets back is from the first resource failure and not e.g. any
resulting exceptions from cancelled in-progress resources.

However, for exceptions thrown in to the task from the outside (as opposed
to raised by one of the subtasks), we generally want the *last* one to be
re-raised. Specifically, if a cancel-without-rollback exception is thrown
followed by a cancel-with-rollback, we want the with-rollback exception to
be re-raised so that the stack knows to roll back.

commit_message:
Raise the last exception thrown into DependencyTaskGroup

Normally when exceptions are caught in DependencyTaskGroup, we cancel with
a grace period and then re-raise the first exception once all subtasks are
stopped. This means that e.g. when a resource fails, the exception the
stack gets back is from the first resource failure and not e.g. any
resulting exceptions from cancelled in-progress resources.

However, for exceptions thrown in to the task from the outside (as opposed
to raised by one of the subtasks), we generally want the *last* one to be
re-raised. Specifically, if a cancel-without-rollback exception is thrown
followed by a cancel-with-rollback, we want the with-rollback exception to
be re-raised so that the stack knows to roll back.

Change-Id: I4843f9a55a4897a7af86a9aa69df073913fd03e6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/64/332964/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Scheduler: Add a progress callback to TaskRunner

This allows the caller to specify an arbitrary function to be called after
each sleep() when running a task. Callers can use this to keep track of
progress or keep track of external state. Any exception raised by the
callback function will be thrown into the task.

Change-Id: I637166f9448169eed8696e5b0fba106b8de1547a

subject: Always call TaskRunner._sleep()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 14:34:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/28b51180e2c3d4c4982723648497bb6ee82e518d', 'message': "Always call TaskRunner._sleep()

In the patch 5f584db8d55a6db76c4307b21cb658a2bacb0296, we avoid calling
TaskRunner._sleep() after the first step if the wait_time is 0 or None.
This is wrong in the case of a wait_time of 0 - since this is distinct from
None, and should result in us calling eventlet.sleep(0). It's also
inconsistent in the case of wait_time=None, since for the rest of the steps
we call self._sleep(None) (and no actual sleep occurs).

This patch ensures we always call self._sleep(), passing 0 or None as
appropriate.

It also enhances the change in d66d57f187c7d8623526e9f928ae76d2cca9ecf9 to
ensure that we never yield from DependencyTaskGroup after all tasks are
completed, which could happen if that last batch of tasks to be started all
completed in a single step. This both saves changing the unit test to
accomodate the new _sleep(None) call and avoids an unnecessary
eventlet.sleep(0) call in real usage.

Change-Id: I301930fcba170e36d2d902c8d693ca722476cd18

commit_message:
Always call TaskRunner._sleep()

In the patch 5f584db8d55a6db76c4307b21cb658a2bacb0296, we avoid calling
TaskRunner._sleep() after the first step if the wait_time is 0 or None.
This is wrong in the case of a wait_time of 0 - since this is distinct from
None, and should result in us calling eventlet.sleep(0). It's also
inconsistent in the case of wait_time=None, since for the rest of the steps
we call self._sleep(None) (and no actual sleep occurs).

This patch ensures we always call self._sleep(), passing 0 or None as
appropriate.

It also enhances the change in d66d57f187c7d8623526e9f928ae76d2cca9ecf9 to
ensure that we never yield from DependencyTaskGroup after all tasks are
completed, which could happen if that last batch of tasks to be started all
completed in a single step. This both saves changing the unit test to
accomodate the new _sleep(None) call and avoids an unnecessary
eventlet.sleep(0) call in real usage.

Change-Id: I301930fcba170e36d2d902c8d693ca722476cd18

commit_message:
Unit tests: add a test resource that takes multiple steps

All of the current test resource types complete in a single step (i.e. have
no check_*_complete() methods). In order to test longer-running resources,
add a resource type in which the number of steps can be specified as a
property.

Change-Id: Ia894efa3207130a187032f2f667c096dee883aea

commit_message:
Avoiding created multiple gateway ports on *one* router gateway

This patch set use feature "trigger" in database. This is useful
in case there are multi concurent request to add gateway ports to
*one* router. Only one request suggest, other request will be
refused.

Change-Id: I59a992842e9cb0e848f5e78d01d19f9beb5a5148
Closes-Bug: #1535225

commit_message:
Enable use of use_neutron flag

For mitaka onwards, use of the 'use_neutron' flag should be made
instead of setting the network API class.

For newton, this is required as the network_api_class is ignored.

Change-Id: Idcf2d080b90909f4b52b45826118d7c6be20ae05

commit_message:
[k8s] Save gateway node ip before its release for proper reporting

During scaling gateways down, reporter was trying to get ip of the
instance which was already released and that caused index error.
This patch saves this ip for report before releasing resourses.

Change-Id: I9310a423b1ad8c488c1cc7400844ae5d8767879c
Closes-bug: #1590728
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-apps refs/changes/33/327833/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Scheduler: Allow TaskRunner to be used as a task

This will be useful in numerous places where we use a TaskRunner to provide
a timeout when we are already inside a wrappertask. It eliminates the
need to manually advance the TaskRunner, and ensures correct exception
handling.

Change-Id: I9be0a361e1d1856adb6eee2ef0da8d5aa23795be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/63/330063/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def as_task(self, timeout=None): """Return a task that drives the TaskRunner.""" resuming = self.started() if not resuming: self.start(timeout=timeout) else: if timeout is not None: new_timeout = Timeout(self, timeout) if self._timeout is None or new_timeout < self._timeout: self._timeout = new_timeout done = self.step() if resuming else self.done() while not done: try: yield except GeneratorExit: self.cancel() raise except: # noqa self._done = True try: self._runner.throw(*sys.exc_info()) except StopIteration: return else: self._done = False else: done = self.step()

commit_message:
Run AuthTokenTests against fernet and uuid

Previously, AuthTokenTests inherited the test structure and ran the tests with
the default keystone configuration. This commit breaks AuthTokenTests to
inherit from `object` and sets up FernetAuthTokenTests and UUIDAuthTokenTests
to setup configuration appropriately and run the tests.

This fix was originally a part of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/258650 but
this is an attempt to break 258650 into smaller, more reviewable, pieces.

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Adam Young <ayound@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I9acacfe7db4997add5505a9ee1972139af11979e
Partial-Bug: 1561054
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/12/343812/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[networking] Add QoS default burst value

Add note about default burst value in underlying
implementation of QoS bandwidth limit rules for Open
vSwitch and Linux bridge agents.

Change-Id: I4e8af070128c33634b14393ec2d964c1f55c6dc1
Closes-Bug: #1582407
Co-Authored-By: Matt Kassawara <mkassawara@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 69d3e328d987092fb560a84a64856fa86a964822)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/42/341942/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: The QoS implementation requires a burst value to ensure proper behavior of bandwidth limit rules in the Open vSwitch and Linux bridge agents. If you do not provide a value, it defaults to 80% of the bandwidth limit which works for typical TCP traffic.

commit_message:
Catch barbicanclient not existing

Causes signature error would then be caught in glance/api/v2/image_data.py
causing the image to be deleted rather than being left in the queued
state.

This stops the 500 being raised and the image left in the queued state.

Change-Id: I885c898c1487c450abdfa7d6a79f526a132fbbcb
Closes-Bug: 1602715

commit_message:
Add support for custom Horizon themes

Deployers can now configure their own custom
themes and set them as the default theme using the
Horizon configuration values AVAILABLE_THEMES and
DEFAULT_THEME

See http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/topics/settings.html#available-themes
for further details on the configuration.

Change-Id: I90b1cb45c851eb654638d82b83af56f93a642895
Closes-Bug: #1590839
(cherry picked from commit 49376929fbce50d730a3379b7e250c8a9f77fe70)

This commit introduces Karma test runner which allows running
Jasmine-based tests in browsers.

commit_message:
Added Webpack integration

This commit allows to create js-openstack-lib build which can be
used in browsers. Webpack library is used to create the build.

Change-Id: I382244c9399cee83720858d0bb2768e9ce3b7c9a

commit_message:
Fix assertEqual usage in test_volume_manage

We pass the response dictionary instead of a message as the third
argument to assertEqual in some unit tests in test_volume_manage.
This patch fixes that usage. It also fixes the order of arguments
in assertEqual.

Change-Id: Ie2a0cc62d551251a1756b3bad459fc9f15b7596c

commit_message:
Added jasmine-based testing harness.

This patch adds jasmine-based testing harnesses for node tests.
A dummy test has also been added to demonstrate use of ES6
features.

commit_message:
Fix OVS agent parameters

Currently we have ovsdb_interface parameter which has docs and
validation for of_interface, but they are two different parameters.

Also added tests.

Related-bug: #1599113

Change-Id: I1caa790d4e4aba614e49ba52138f78407bbb69c0
(cherry picked from commit 220a903333dbf654db34917d5e425d52705fe673)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/94/344694/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*of_interface*]# [*ovsdb_interface*] # (optional) The interface for interacting with the OVSDB # Allowed values: vsctl, native # Defaults to $::os_service_default # $of_interface = $::os_service_default, if ! (is_service_default($of_interface)) and ! ($of_interface =~ /^(ovs-ofctl|native)$/) { fail('A value of $of_interface is incorrect. The allowed values are ovs-ofctl and native') } if ! (is_service_default($ovsdb_interface)) and ! ($ovsdb_interface =~ /^(vsctl|native)$/) { fail('A value of $ovsdb_interface is incorrect. The allowed values are vsctl and native') 'ovs/of_interface': value => $of_interface;
deleted_lines: # [*ovsdb_interface*] if ! (is_service_default($ovsdb_interface)) and ! ($ovsdb_interface =~ /^(ovs-ofctl|native)$/) { fail('A value of $ovsdb_interface is incorrect. The allowed values are ovs-ofctl and native')

commit_message:
Resolves issue where to allow custom repo URLS

Using an centos7 image and changing the HDP and HDP-UTILS URL location
resulted in an error of
"os_type=os_type_map[client.get_host_info[ambari.fqdn())["os_type"]]
KeyError: u'centos7'. This results in only being able to change the
HDP and HDP-UTILS URL if you were using centos6 or redhat6.This change
adds centos7 and redhat7 to the map to allow custom HDP and HDP-UTILS URLs.

Should we add additional operating systems to the list?

Closes-Bug: #1599252

Change-Id: Iaa5cd773c5daeabeda287048a2d3f8696faa1436
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/62/339962/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "redhat6": "redhat6", "centos7": "redhat7", "redhat7": "redhat7"

commit_message:
sleep before waiting requests

to avoid issue with fast completing requests we need
to sleep a little before actual waiting for requests.

Closes-bug: 1596553
Change-Id: I17993f091241243eea670c7cf591ddd9c23d069c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/78/334178/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Invoke babel to generate a ES5-compatible library.

This patch creates a very simple index.js file which uses
ES2015. It then creates a very simple Babel compile step
which converts this into a usable library.

Change-Id: I6a64843793297bcf784372002853d506f348c0d5

commit_message:
Restore check/audit test in tox.ini

The check/audit mode test in tox.ini was removed in
If42e739002e36669044a9396e233dbd382add4c8 with the tox.ini cleanup.
This patch adds it back into tox.ini so that it runs prior to the
functional tests.

Change-Id: I1842c8170ec532baf713ab789ffe389369c5e48e

commit_message:
Add an ability to configure root_helper_daemon

To increase performance and don't call everytime
sudo it's possible to enable rootwrap demon to 'proxy' sudo calls.

Change-Id: Ie7765cd4aa41f95eb498a4132c38937b2817f8e8
(cherry picked from commit 62fbfc48ecbe3a9f0da8cc9112fa9b64da80112e)

commit_message:
py3: Replace map/filter with a list comprehension

The map and filter functions returns a list in python 2 but
an iterator in python 3. However, there are instances where
the code assumes the returned value from map/value to be a
list. Substitute these functions to its list comprehension
equivalent expression to enable compatibility with Python 3.

Change-Id: Iccaa3d1f4b009f59ea575c955ee4015e964f2318

commit_message:
Enable use of use_neutron flag

For mitaka onwards, use of the 'use_neutron' flag should be made
instead of setting the network API class.

For newton, this is required as the network_api_class is ignored.

Change-Id: Ifb359d0a3d2a84f0f3bc4cbb944efdde7866950a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/99/344799/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: use_neutron = True

commit_message:
Enable use of use_neutron flag

For mitaka onwards, use of the 'use_neutron' flag should be made
instead of setting the network API class.

For newton, this is required as the network_api_class is ignored.

Change-Id: I843d82eb0518a0c27858816becf0f8b392bdb5eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-cloud-controller refs/changes/01/344801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: use_neutron = True

commit_message:
Fix improperly placed firewall.update_filters when aborting

Currently, firewall.update_filters() is called before introspection
finished, which has no effect as it white-lists MAC addresses that
are under introspection.

Change-Id: I789e39a86dc72470b80167e53f1755b506ca6f44
Closes-Bug: #1548806
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/44/344544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # block this node from PXE Booting the introspection image try: firewall.update_filters(ironic) except Exception as exc: # Note(mkovacik): this will be retried in firewall update # periodic task; we continue aborting LOG.warning(_LW('Failed to update firewall filters: %s'), exc, node_info=node_info)
deleted_lines: # block this node from PXE Booting the introspection image try: firewall.update_filters(ironic) except Exception as exc: # Note(mkovacik): this will be retried in firewall update # periodic task; we continue aborting LOG.warning(_LW('Failed to update firewall filters: %s'), exc, node_info=node_info)

commit_message:
Improve the help text for the network options (4)

The previous commit moved all the options from nova/network/manager.py
to a central location in nova/conf/network.py. This commit adds
additional help text to those options. Because of the large number of
options, the improved help text will be split into several patches; this
is patch 4 of 4.

Blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I06d9a76afe6a926db5f3f689b212f2562dbb6a92

commit_message:
Make ::tripleo::profile::base classes work with multiple nodes

In the Next Generation HA architecture a number of active/active services
will be run via systemd. In order for this to work we need to make sure that
the sync_db operation only takes place on the bootstrap node, just like it is
done today for the pacemaker profiles.

We do this by removing sync_db as a parameter and instead set it to true
or false depending if the hostname matches the bootstrap_node as it is done
today in the pacemaker role.

Note that we call hiera('bootstrap_nodeid', undef) because if a profile
is included on a non controller node that variable will be undefined.

The following testing was done:
- HA puppet-pacemaker.yaml scenario with three computes
- NonHA with one controller
- NonHA with three controllers

Fixes-Bug: 1600149

Co-Author: cmsj@tenshu.net

Change-Id: I04a7b9e3c18627ea512000a34357acb7f27d6e0e
Implements: blueprint ha-lightweight-architecture
