commit_message:
Use osd-upgrade user for pause/resume

The pause and resume actions shell out to the ceph command to run
OSD operations (in/out).

Because the default cephx key given out by the monitor cluster does
not contain the correct permissions, these commands fail.

Use the osd-upgrade user which has the correct permissions.

Closes-Bug: 1602826

Depends-On: I6af43b61149c6eeeeb5c77950701194beda2da71
Change-Id: Ie31bc9048972dbb0986ac8deb5b821a4db5d585f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-osd refs/changes/37/342437/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "ceph_user", self.ceph_user.return_value = "ceph" cmd = ['sudo', '-u', 'ceph', 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-upgrade', 'osd', 'out', '5'] "ceph_user", self.ceph_user.return_value = "ceph" cmd = ['sudo', '-u', 'ceph', 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-upgrade', 'osd', 'in', '5']

commit_message:
Fix OSD replacement

Use the osd-upgrade key when replacing OSD's as this key
has the correct cephx permissions to perform the operation.

Closes-Bug: 1602826

Depends-On: I6af43b61149c6eeeeb5c77950701194beda2da71
Change-Id: I32d2f1a4036e09d5d1fd13009c95ab1514e7304c

commit_message:
Adding Tacker functional tests with parameterization using tosca template

Closes-bug: #1594599
Depends-On: I8f7c36333ae26a88f52fe06883a9bfe8efdcf731

Change-Id: Ibdedb6b6d1d5f2fd01dc55443bf6e6ed0e580392
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker refs/changes/97/332097/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tosca_definitions_version: tosca_simple_profile_for_nfv_1_0_0 description: VNF TOSCA template with input parameters metadata: template_name: sample-tosca-vnfd topology_template: inputs: image_name: type: string description: Image Name flavor: type: string description: Flavor Information zone: type: string description: Zone Information network: type: string description: mgmt network management: type: string description: management network pkt_in_network: type: string description: In network pkt_out_network: type: string description: Out network vendor: type: string description: Vendor information node_templates: VDU1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VDU.Tacker properties: image: { get_input: image_name} flavor: {get_input: flavor} availability_zone: { get_input: zone } mgmt_driver: noop config: | param0: key1 param1: key2 CP1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: management: { get_input: management } anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL1 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 CP2: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL2 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 CP3: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL3 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 VL1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: { get_input: network } vendor: {get_input: vendor} VL2: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: { get_input: pkt_in_network } vendor: {get_input: vendor} VL3: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: { get_input: pkt_out_network } vendor: {get_input: vendor}

subject: Use constraints for coverage job
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 14:08:49.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/efa3dee6138f4e807171c2c19cfc1684bc3c232c', 'message': 'Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first

commit_message:
Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first
job to check that the recent changes for zuul-cloner work correctly.

Use constraints for cover environment.

Change-Id: I81a985a2049221a8a7ac1f20642137f22847973f
(cherry picked from commit d2b2cc80e97b7bd05f8dff32d0fd25d8c20fbb5a)

commit_message:
Remove old ceph apt sources config

We have successfully migrated the devstack-plugin-ceph repo over to
using the opt in apt sources list for ceph mirroring. They were the
consumer of this so we can remove having it installed by default now.

Change-Id: Ibb3f906e673aa86ad1222e52d3a1c96104b0a00c

deleted_lines: #!/bin/bash . /etc/sysconfig/heat-params echo "Configuring mesos (agent)" myip=$(ip addr show eth0 | awk '$1 == "inet" {print $2}' | cut -f1 -d/) zk="" for master_ip in $MESOS_MASTERS_IPS; do zk="${zk}${master_ip}:2181," done # Remove last ',' zk=${zk::-1} # Zookeeper URL. This specifies how to connect to a quorum of masters # Format: zk://host1:port1,...,hostN:portN/path echo "zk://${zk}/mesos" > /etc/mesos/zk # The hostname the agent should report echo "$myip" > /etc/mesos-agent/hostname # The IP address to listen on echo "$myip" > /etc/mesos-agent/ip # List of containerizer implementations echo "docker,mesos" > /etc/mesos-agent/containerizers # Amount of time to wait for an executor to register cat > /etc/mesos-agent/executor_registration_timeout <<EOF $EXECUTOR_REGISTRATION_TIMEOUT EOF if [ -n "$ISOLATION" ]; then echo "$ISOLATION" > /etc/mesos-agent/isolation fi if [ -n "$WORK_DIR" ]; then echo "$WORK_DIR" > /etc/mesos-agent/work_dir fi if [ -n "$IMAGE_PROVIDERS" ]; then if [ -n "$ISOLATION" ]; then echo "$IMAGE_PROVIDERS" > /etc/mesos-agent/image_providers else echo "isolation doesn't exist, not setting image_providers" fi fi if [ -n "$EXECUTOR_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES" ]; then echo "$EXECUTOR_ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLES" > /etc/executor_environment_variables echo "file:///etc/executor_environment_variables" > /etc/mesos-agent/executor_environment_variables fi

commit_message:
Introduce microversion-parse package

We were doing some parsing of the micro-version header by ourselves
while there is a community wide package doing the same thing. This patch
proposes a migration to use the 'microversion-parse' package for this
job.

Change-Id: I47b7021509e24a9f103a494a97fe50d8dfb99b7c

subject: Fix the issue introduced by Neutron in _add_network_segment
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 01:42:37.000000000', 'files': ['tricircle/network/managers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tricircle/commit/7d2e179cc360f41aecfbb0c9ef8df485edcb6f67', 'message': 'Fix the issue introduced by Neutron in _add_network_segment

1.What is the problem
The Tricircle Neutron plugin will call Neutron type manager's
function _add_network_segement, the first parameter of this
function was "session" in the past, but Neutron has changed
the parameter to "context" recently, this makes the check
and gate test in the Tricircle failed because the Tricircle
still pass "session" as the first parameter.

and any new patch is not able to be merged. The issue should
be fixed ASAP.

Pass "context" but not "session" to the function

3.What is the purpose of this patch set:
To get rid of the failure in check and gate test failure.

Signed-off-by: Chaoyi Huang <joehuang@huawei.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the issue introduced by Neutron in _add_network_segment

1.What is the problem
The Tricircle Neutron plugin will call Neutron type manager's
function _add_network_segement, the first parameter of this
function was "session" in the past, but Neutron has changed
the parameter to "context" recently, this makes the check
and gate test in the Tricircle failed because the Tricircle
still pass "session" as the first parameter.

All check and gate test of python27 failed due to this change,
and any new patch is not able to be merged. The issue should
be fixed ASAP.

2.What's need to be fixed:
Pass "context" but not "session" to the function
_add_network_segement.

3.What is the purpose of this patch set:
To get rid of the failure in check and gate test failure.

Change-Id: I78c64fe3cdd939cbdecf35fec0cff6cb44746cb0
Signed-off-by: Chaoyi Huang <joehuang@huawei.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/24/344524/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: self._add_network_segment(session, network_id, segment, self._add_network_segment(session, network_id, segment, mtu)

Trivial: use stripped path when doing collect

This is a trivial patch that ensures the cluster collect RPC call is
using the stripped path value (if any).

Change-Id: Ifd2d6801846c5632f3a6a8e164eab0428d81c64f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/85/343985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pass auth_token in auth_ref

In our env, keystone was looking for auth_token inside auth_ref
while trying to construct the client. This resulted in an exception.
This patch fixed the problem.

Closes-Bug: #1604532

Change-Id: I101cf72f61dd824cb62f7f2b6d42ade6e7f3b1c3

commit_message:
Fix the failure to create instance snapshot

When making snapshot for instance with ceph enabled, nova will use
upate image api to create the snapshot directly. with the patchset
I7284dee828bc8ca00747bc7668b37fa7176afc85 in Glance, the
show_multiple_locations must be True.

Change-Id: Ic9612566e2ab8f641030fef97b519f11d942a915
Closes-Bug: #1604464
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/09/344309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a hacking rule for string interpolation at logging

String interpolation should be delayed to be handled
by the logging code, rather than being done
at the point of the logging call.
So add a hacking rule for it.

See the oslo i18n guideline.

* http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html

Change-Id: I91e8d59d508c594256d5f74514e62f8f928d1df5
Closes-Bug: #1596829

commit_message:
3par driver handles concurrent host create conflict

One of the step in creating a FC VLUN is to create a host on array.
When there happens to have simultaneous request for creating same host,
hpe3parclient will create host for one and return HTTP 409 conflict for others,
with error code 73, message "host WWN/iSCSI name already used by another host".
This was not handled by 3PAR driver and the HTTP exception would propagate up to
volume manager where it would log it. This patch addresses this bug by catching
this exception and reusing the same host.

Change-Id: I66e4f80696c782ab869ef0d7848fc6f3b3100c04
Closes-Bug: #1597454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/335695/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 3.0.8 - Handling HTTP conflict 409, host WWN/iSCSI name already used by another host, while creating 3PAR FC Host. bug #1597454 VERSION = "3.0.8" try: common.client.createHost(hostname, FCWwns=wwns, optional={'domain': domain, 'persona': persona_id}) except hpeexceptions.HTTPConflict as path_conflict: msg = ("FC host creation caught " "HTTP conflict code: %s" % path_conflict.get_code()) LOG.debug(msg) # EXISTENT_PATH error code returned from hpe3parclient EXISTENT_PATH = 73 if path_conflict.get_code() is EXISTENT_PATH: # Handle exception : EXISTENT_PATH - host WWN/iSCSI name # already used by another host hosts = common.client.queryHost(wwns=wwns) if hosts and hosts['members'] and ( 'name' in hosts['members'][0]): hostname = hosts['members'][0]['name'] else: # re rasise last caught exception raise else: # re rasise last caught exception for other HTTP conflict raise
deleted_lines: VERSION = "3.0.7" common.client.createHost(hostname, FCWwns=wwns, optional={'domain': domain, 'persona': persona_id})

commit_message:
[contributor] reorganize documentation tools

Reorganizes the Documentation tools section basing on
the principles of topic-based authoring.

Co-Authored-By: OlgaGusarenko <ogusarenko@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I2f23828672dea091279ee53650275ed9ca48705b
Implements: blueprint contributor-guide-reorg
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/95/339995/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Documentation ToolsSome documentation files are automatically generated and these should not be modified by hand. They contain a ``do not edit`` warning at the beginning of the file and should only be generated using the ``openstack-doc-tools`` tool kit. openstack-doc-tools ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The `openstack-doc-tools <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-doc-tools>`_https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-doc-tools/tree/doc/source. CLI reference ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The ``doc/cli-reference`` directory contains documentation for the `OpenStack command-line clients <http://docs.openstack.org/cli-reference/>`_. Most of these files are generated using the ``openstack-auto-commands`` tool found in the ``openstack-doc-tools`` repository. See the repository file ``os_doc_tools/resources/clients.yaml`` for a list of supported clients. The generated files can be found in ``doc/cli-reference/source``. .. important:: Some files are still manually maintained. If unsure, look for the warning at the top of the file before attempting to re-generate it. Automated generation -------------------- Within the ``openstack-doc-tools`` repository, there is a script to automate submission of an update to a client CLI documentation file. The following instructions demonstrate how to use this script using nova as an example client CLI. Clone the tools repo. .. code-block:: console $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools $ cd openstack-doc-tools/bin Run the automated script. This will generate a virtual environment. This will install the necessary software and run the tool to re-generate the file. .. code-block:: console $ ./doc-tools-update-cli-reference nova The script will have cloned the ``openstack-manuals`` repo and created a commit with the newly generated file. Check that the file looks correct and if you are satisfied with it, submit it for review. .. code-block:: console $ cd openstack-manuals $ git status $ git show $ git review .. important:: If inspection of the generated file reveals typographical errors or incorrect content, **do not fix these**. They must be fixed in the corresponding client repository (typically by adjusting the help strings for the various commands). Once the change has merged and a new client released, a new CLI documentation file can be generated with the updated content. Manual generation ----------------- Sometimes it may be necessary to re-generate these files manually. To do this, you must have ``openstack-doc-tools`` installed. .. code-block:: console $ pip install openstack-doc-tools To ensure that you have the latest tool changes, clone the repository. This is also necessary if you make changes to the tool in order to generate a proper file. .. code-block:: console $ pushd <work_dir> $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools $ cd openstack-doc-tools $ pip install . $ cd .. Change to the ``doc/cli-reference/source`` directory of your ``openstack-manuals`` clone and run the ``openstack-auto-commands`` command. .. code-block:: console $ cd /path/to/openstack-manuals/doc/cli-reference/source $ openstack-auto-commands --all To generate a specific CLI file, run: .. code-block:: console $ openstack-auto-commands <client_name> To check a list of available options, run: .. code-block:: console $ openstack-auto-commands --help Once you finish updating the generated files, submit them in a usual manner.

Customize Horizon Help URL

This change modifies the help url configuration property to point to a
url of user's choice with proper horizon_config attribute.

Closes bug: #1578008

added_lines: .. list-table:: OpenStack command-line clients prerequisites :header-rows: 1 :widths: 20 80 * - Prerequisite - Description * - Python 2.7 or later - Currently, the clients do not support Python 3. * - setuptools package - Installed by default on Mac OS X. Many Linux distributions provide packages to make setuptools easy to install. Search your package manager for setuptools to find an installation package. If you cannot find one, download the setuptools package directly from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools. The recommended way to install setuptools on Microsoft Windows is to follow the documentation provided on the setuptools website (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools). Another option is to use the unofficial binary installer maintained by Christoph Gohlke (http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#setuptools). * - pip package - To install the clients on a Linux, Mac OS X, or Microsoft Windows system, use pip. It is easy to use, ensures that you get the latest version of the clients from the `Python Package Index <https://pypi.python.org/>`__, and lets you update or remove the packages later on. Since the installation process compiles source files, this requires the related Python development package for your operating system and distribution. Install pip through the package manager for your system: **MacOS** .. code-block:: console # easy_install pip **Microsoft Windows** Ensure that the ``C:\Python27\Scripts`` directory is defined in the ``PATH`` environment variable, and use the ``easy_install`` command from the setuptools package: .. code-block:: console C:\>easy_install pip Another option is to use the unofficial binary installer provided by Christoph Gohlke (http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#pip). **Ubuntu or Debian** .. code-block:: console # apt install python-dev python-pip Note that extra dependencies may be required, per operating system, depending on the package being installed, such as is the case with Tempest. **Red Hat Enterprise Linux, CentOS, or Fedora** A packaged version enables you to use yum to install the package: .. code-block:: console # yum install python-devel python-pip There are also packaged versions of the clients available in `RDO <https://www.rdoproject.org/>`__ that enable yum to install the clients as described in Installing_from_packages_. **SUSE Linux Enterprise Server** A packaged version available in `the Open Build Service <https://build.opensuse.org/package/show?package=python-pip&project=Cloud:OpenStack:Master>`__ enables you to use YaST or zypper to install the package. First, add the Open Build Service repository: .. code-block:: console # zypper addrepo -f obs://Cloud:OpenStack:Liberty/SLE_12 Liberty Then install pip and use it to manage client installation: .. code-block:: console # zypper install python-devel python-pip There are also packaged versions of the clients available that enable zypper to install the clients as described in Installing_from_packages_. **openSUSE** You can install pip and use it to manage client installation: .. code-block:: console # zypper install python-devel python-pip There are also packaged versions of the clients available that enable zypper to install the clients as described in Installing_from_packages_.

Adding identity ng-roles panel

This patch adds a angular roles table.

To be added in subsequent patches:

added_lines: On network nodes: Add the qos service to the service_plugins setting in /etc/neutron/neutron.conf. For example: service_plugins = neutron.services.l3_router.l3_router_plugin.L3RouterPlugin,neutron.services.metering.metering_plugin.MeteringPlugin,neutron.services.qos.qos_plugin.QoSPlugin Optionally, set the needed notification_drivers in the [qos] section in /etc/neutron/neutron.conf (messaging is the default). In /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini, add qos to extension_drivers in the [ml2] section. For example: [ml2] extension_drivers = port_security,qos On compute nodes: In /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini, add qos to the extensions setting in the [agent] section. For example: [agent] extensions = qos
deleted_lines: On server side: * Enable ``qos`` service in ``service_plugins``. * Set the needed ``notification_drivers`` in ``[qos]`` section (``messaging`` is the default). * For ml2, add ``qos`` to ``extension_drivers`` in ``[ml2]`` section. On agent side: * Add ``qos`` to extensions in ``[agent]`` section.

Change-Id: Ib0a61175bd9af3014db445514e7e52f2369361b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/74/342874/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =============================== Murano application from scratch =============================== Main goal of this document is to demonstrate whole process of developing, testing and publishing a simple Murano application. As an example, I consider the RefStack client application. It is a very simple app, basically it just spawns an instance in a cloud, accessible from our laptop by ssh and run installation on it. So, as a result, user gets ready environment to work with refstack-client in a cloud. This usecase looks simple, but can be useful, in case user don't want or can't install some software on your laptop. It is good fit for refstack-client because it has lots of binary dependencies and at the same time have to have access to the cloud endpoints. Murano basics ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To understand how Murano works, it important to become familiar with following terms: application, bundle, catalog, environment. Application it is a minimal part of the picture. Basically it is recipe of how to deploy some service. It can be standalone application like, for example, WordPress-based web site or your own in-house instance of Gitlab and it also can be packaged service like LDAP or MySQL. Applications can be connected to gather. So it is possible to deploy one big meta-application consist of set smaller apps. Like, for example, WordPress-based web site will consist from Apache server, MySQL data base, Nginx proxy and so on. Due to deliver such meta-application with a single binaty artifact user can use bundles, which are just set of applications packaged in to single archive. Murano allows user to browse through imported apps using catalog. Catalog it is just a dashboard for the set of user's apps. From the catalog user can add application to environment and trigger environment deployment. Environment is functional unit. It is a place where applications recipes are actually applies to cluster . User can manage its life cycle. Environment has set of owned resources like VMs, networks, etc. It pretty close to Heat stack entity. Basically each environment is based of Heat stack. Murano package ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ What parts murano package consists of? Simple answer is: from classes with logic-based configuration, set of resources, like files, UI definitions and metadata. In case of RefStack client, a structure of the package looks like this:: .. |_ Classes | |_ RefStackClient.yaml | |_ RefStackClientTest.yaml | |_ Resources | |_ installRefStackClient.sh | |_ env-fixture.json | |_ UI | |_ ui.yaml | |_ logo.png | |_ manifest.yaml Files content can be found in the application `repository <https://github.com/openstack/murano-apps/tree/master/RefStackClient/package>`__ The detailed information regarding the package structure can be found in the Murano developer documentation in `Murano packages <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/murano/draft/appdev-guide/murano_packages.html#murano-packages>`__ section. MuranoPL class ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The center of any Murano application are classes written in MuranoPL. Classes are valid yaml files, so can be considered as logic-based configuration. On the one hand it is program written in object-oriented language, in other hand it is a piece of configuration can be safely uploaded into cloud and executed there. So, Murano class it is a peace of code can be safely executed in cloud. Something like AWS Lambda, but with own DSL. All application classes are located in the ``Classes`` folder. RefStack client has two classes. ``RefStackClient.yaml`` with application logic and ``RefStackClientTest`` with test for this application. UI form definition ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ One of advantages of Murano is a support if UI form definition. It allows user to describe UI in simple yaml file and Murano will generate set of Horizon-look-like forms based on this configuration. Application ----------- TBD Forms ----- TBD Application unit tests ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Murano applications can be ans should tested. Due to dynamic nature of MuranoPL it is very difficult get to know if something is wrong in written code before it will actually executed. Due to for MuranoPL execution means real deployment, it would be nice to have a possibility to check code correctness in local environment, without real deployment. And Murano offers such feature! Setup environment for test execution ------------------------------------ TBD Murano testing framework ------------------------ TBD Test example ------------ TBD Preparing package and publishing ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Landing application code in catalog repository ---------------------------------------------- TBD Publishing package to OpenStack application catalog --------------------------------------------------- TBD Conclusion ~~~~~~~~~~ TBD

commit_message:
VNFD Legacy templates deprecated

Throws a deprecation warning while using legacy templates for VNF
creation.

Change-Id: Ie68389e4abd0c7293ec48ed2a380fb7956d8c599
Partial-Bug: #1582928

added_lines: Legacy Template Deprecate Warning ================================= From Mitaka version, Tacker supports TOSCA based VNFD templates. Legacy templates described under tacker/sample/legacy-templates are deprecated. Use TOSCA based templates described at tacker/sample/tosca-templates/vnfd

commit_message:
Support service-specific rabbitmq clusters

The ceilometer middleware used to send swift notifications
now uses the ceilometer-specific vars:
 * ceilometer_rabbitmq_host_group
 * ceilometer_rabbitmq_port

Change-Id: I7a8d971bf2e6b1b8093789950166c912cf014d1e
Implements: blueprint multi-rabbitmq-clusters

commit_message:
Support newer mysql in tests

Newer mysql cli clients emit a warning when you put a password on the
cli. This warning was being interpreted as a failure by the test
framework. Change the framework to accept the warning or empty string as
valid responses when running the mysql cli client to support using the
cli client in the trove tests.

I am not entirely sure when this new behavior arrived in mysql but it is
present in Ubuntu Xenial's Mysql 5.7 packages.

Change-Id: Ia148d72a7646f4c424139232d6388ff14d1d8686
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/48/341248/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: assert_equal('', err, "Failed to run: '%(cmd)s' " "Output: '%(stdout)s' " "Error: '%(stderr)s'" % {'cmd': cmd, 'stdout': out, 'stderr': err})

subject: Serialize py34 tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 17:52:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/245e55409b023711cbad72c26407e264d8bed870', 'message': 'Add lock around run_tests db create

Add a locking mechanism around run_tests
database generation.

This is another attempt to have the py34 tests
run more stable in the gate.

A previous changeset added this to the unittests
util method, however the issue still manifests
itself occationally.
See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/343048

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3

Change-Id: I530fcf22b697148a3d0a286015c5a79481528d8e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-19 18:43:29.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/798d9354f679292a23c825a865097e9f0e3d105f', 'message': "Serialize py34 tests

It turns out that the way the python34 tests are run in parallel is
to spin up several processes (not threads).  This means that putting
locks around creating the database in a single 'run' would need an
inter-process lock not a thread lock.

While the feasibility of this is investigated, change the behaviour
of the tests to run in series to increase stability.

On a 4 cpu test machine this only increased the run time by 70s.

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3

Change-Id: I530fcf22b697148a3d0a286015c5a79481528d8e
"}]
commit_message:
Serialize py34 tests

It turns out that the way the python34 tests are run in parallel is
to spin up several processes (not threads).  This means that putting
locks around creating the database in a single 'run' would need an
inter-process lock not a thread lock.

While the feasibility of this is investigated, change the behaviour
of the tests to run in series to increase stability.

On a 4 cpu test machine this only increased the run time by 70s.

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3

Change-Id: I530fcf22b697148a3d0a286015c5a79481528d8e

commit_message:
Blacklist oslo.context 2.6.0

The 2.6.0 release has an API change to the RequestContext
class init:

d3af1d06b4046c25c199bf1c389a9e440a634bc6

That's breaking nova jobs now that upper-constraints is using
2.6.0.

That change needs to be coordinated, and it should have triggered
a major version bump for oslo.context.

Change-Id: I9d0e19efa950192103de5ddf6326fa481d00688f
Related-Bug: #1603979

commit_message:
Add is_admin_project to context

is_admin_project is provided by keystonemiddleware and used by
oslo.policy to enforce that a project scoped token exists in the admin
project.

To make this usable we add the ability to read the X-Is-Admin-Project
header from the environment, and add it to the outputted policy values.

Note the value is added to keystonemiddleware in the depend review
however it must work even with older auth_token middlewares so is fine
to merge prior to a middleware release.

Closes-Bug: #1577996
Depends-On: Ic680e6eaa683926914cf4b2152ec3bb67c6601ff
Change-Id: Ie48fedb8092e33e9645a37ea3fe44b88d34ad3b8

added_lines: resource_uuid=None, overwrite=True, roles=None, is_admin_project=True): self.is_admin_project = is_admin_project 'roles': self.roles, 'is_admin_project': self.is_admin_project} if 'is_admin_project' not in kwargs: # NOTE(jamielennox): we default is_admin_project to true because if # nothing is provided we have to assume it is the admin project to # make old policy continue to work. is_admin_proj_str = environ.get('HTTP_X_IS_ADMIN_PROJECT', 'true') kwargs['is_admin_project'] = is_admin_proj_str.lower() == 'true'

commit_message:
WIP: Switch doc to use to neutron by default.

Change I1304a605fc4b1a832036bd98b5bfd0d630d6fe56 in the Nova
project officially deprecates nova networking and encourages a shift to
neutron networks instead.  This is due to OpenStack User Survey feedback
that less than 10% of users are still utilizing nova networks.

Given this signaling, it seems appropriate to update the devstack
documentation to default to neutron networking.

Change-Id: Iec63cb5755f31c20fde15fc911b816169764fea5

commit_message:
Correct reraising of exception

when an exception was caught and rethrown, it should call 'raise'
without any arguments.

Change-Id: Ie40b4bfade6298f2168c3292386dd94ffea48757
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/84/338784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except exception.SecurityGroupCreationError: raise except exception.SecurityGroupRuleCreationError: raise
deleted_lines: except exception.SecurityGroupCreationError as e: raise e except exception.SecurityGroupRuleCreationError as e: raise e

commit_message:
Fix the computed constraints

The current constraints file is generated from a template, which
completely recreates the url used for the constraints.
Therefore, it deletes previously given arguments, like subdirectories.

This commit replaces the initial url to the local (previously fetched)
repo, so the constraints generation behavior stays consistent.

Change-Id: I5fe202ddb38b99e4631bfc40fc360cfd5702d993
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk>
(Ported from commit 474db96286b06597cbda4736c939f51b594dafa3)

commit_message:
Improve the help text for the network options (3)

The previous commit moved all the options from nova/network/manager.py
to a central location in nova/conf/network.py. This commit adds
additional help text to those options. Because of the large number of
options, the improved help text will be split into several patches; this
is patch 3 of 4.

Blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: Iec4edc688d74b0ecdfd7ee8a0a1ad9b5ea153ed0

commit_message:
Improve the help text for the network options (2)

The previous commit moved all the options from nova/network/manager.py
to a central location in nova/conf/network.py. This commit adds
additional help text to those options. Because of the large number of
options, the improved help text will be split into several patches; this
is patch 2 of 4.

Blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I3900aa874810a8d6aa60d5015e6613b9f0cf5b55

Possible values: Any valid IP address * Services that use this: ``nova-network`` * Related options: vpn_start """), default=1000, help=""" This is the port number to use as the first VPN port for private networks. Please note that this option is only used when using nova-network instead of Neutron in your deployment. Possible values: Any integer representing a valid port number. The default is 1000. * Services that use this: ``nova-network`` * Related options: vpn_ip """), default=256, help=""" This option determines the number of addresses in each private subnet. The default is 256. Please note that this option is only used when using nova-network instead of Neutron in your deployment. Possible values: Any positive integer that is less than or equal to the available network size. Note that if you are creating multiple networks, they must all fit in the available IP address space. * Services that use this: ``nova-network`` * Related options: None """), default="fd00::/48", help=""" This option determines the fixed IPv6 address block when creating a network. commit_message:
Fix show/hide password when clicking password icon

This patch overrides a Bootstrap's default property that disables
mouse events on elements with .form-control-feedback class. The password
icon had pointer-events: none; affecting password reveal functionality
in login form and Identity->Users->Create User. It also modifies the default
cursor for the password icon with pointer.

This patch also fixes a bug where the Eye Icon is misaligned when passwords
don't match (See #1604196)

Change-Id: I052321a5cc9adc1a7ffdfce4da0b55c245481a2d
Closes-bug: #1593430
Closes-bug: #1604196
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/33/343833/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .password-icon { cursor: pointer; pointer-events: auto; }

subject: Use SAML2 requests plugin
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-09 03:28:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth/commit/6486a68fed27409a647a4f5b54e6dbdd55136978', 'message': "Use SAML2 requests plugin

This is a major refactoring of the SAML2 plugin to move the logic into a
standalone requests auth plugin, and then have the keystoneauth plugin
simply provide a wrapper around that.

There was really no way to migrate this and keep the existing test files
as they were because the entire structure has been changed.

This will be the recommended way to do federation plugins in future and
keep the auth logic out of keystoneauth as much as possible (as kerberos
already does).

The intention will be that later we should be able to extract the SAML
ECP requests plugin into it's own upstream module.

Change-Id: I4a7377b9350741e8f7a4ed2a49a7e2442eacdd23
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-12-09 03:46:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth/commit/26cdee427c0e1bec46c3682f011e7132a32d225a', 'message': "Use SAML2 requests plugin

This is a major refactoring of the SAML2 plugin to move the logic into a
standalone requests auth plugin, and then have the keystoneauth plugin

commit_message:
Use SAML2 requests plugin

This is a major refactoring of the SAML2 plugin to move the logic into a
standalone requests auth plugin, and then have the keystoneauth plugin
simply provide a wrapper around that.

There was really no way to migrate this and keep the existing test files
as they were because the entire structure has been changed.

This will be the recommended way to do federation plugins in future and
keep the auth logic out of keystoneauth as much as possible (as kerberos
already does).

The intention will be that later we should be able to extract the SAML
ECP requests plugin into it's own upstream module.

Change-Id: I4a7377b9350741e8f7a4ed2a49a7e2442eacdd23

commit_message:
Console log copy for block live migration

Fix problem of console log file lost during
block live migration by copying this file
from destination using scp and then swap with
console.log created by libvirt.

Change-Id: Ib026009be41744ab6057133493829b8e9e61972d
Closes-Bug: #1203193

Since the AZ cache creates more problems than it resolves, we prefer to remove it

   related to it (for example, when it's not scheduled), it creates some confusion

commit_message:
Remove cache from the AZ helper

Since the AZ cache creates more problems than it resolves, we prefer to remove it
from the AZ helper module.
To be clear, there are a few problems with the cache :
 - it's keyed by hosts, not by instances but since an instance can have no hosts
   related to it (for example, when it's not scheduled), it creates some confusion
 - if an instance is not yet scheduled, it returns the default AZ while it should
   return None instead
 - the above creates some bugs with flapping AZs for some instances (see bug #1390033)
 - there is no real beating reason for using a MC for getting something internal
   (in an helper module) while it could maybe be far more appealing either close
   to the model or to the API

Change-Id: Id59faf5a0c04569963e9a46b7575dae108546727
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/221384/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: linux_net: retry ovs vif port creation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-11 18:19:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b5241056ced24a0fd444e9dde73ff462907bcde4', 'message': "linux_net: retry ovs vif port creation

When a host is rebooted and resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set
to True, it may happen that nova-compute starts before Neutron L2
agent finishes its initialization, which includes creation of an OVS
integration bridge, and thus we'll see the following error when
creating an ovs vif port:

    ovs-vsctl: no bridge named br-int

An instance will be booted successfully, but there will be no network
connectivity inside the VM.

Retry ovs vif port creation to give Neutron L2 agent some time to
create the integration bridge.

Closes-Bug: #1532890

Change-Id: I5d3815c403098b2071da0ede21208ab7dc358edb
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-12 21:16:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e8d2a09a7e0d3848c7fac34315479440e411e94e', 'message': "linux_net: retry ovs vif port creation

When a host is rebooted and resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set
to True, it may happen that nova-compute starts before OVS finishes
initialization of all created bridges, and thus we'll see the
following error when creating an ovs vif port:

    ovs-vsctl: no bridge named br-int

An instance will be booted successfully, but there will be no network
connectivity inside the VM.

In init systems like upstart this dependency between services can not
be expressed easily as the fact OVS started does not mean it has
finished its initialization and created all necessary bridges. We
would need an explicit notification sent by OVS to ensure all edge
cases are covered.

Retry an ovs vif port creation to give OVS some time to complete its
initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1532890

Change-Id: I5d3815c403098b2071da0ede21208ab7dc358edb
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-18 11:38:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4117f313cb5fde8a5f5fba2830d5addf6afd6293', 'message': "linux_net: retry ovs vif port creation

When a host is rebooted and resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set
to True, it may happen that nova-compute starts before OVS finishes
initialization of all created bridges, and thus we'll see the
following error when creating an ovs vif port:

    ovs-vsctl: no bridge named br-int

An instance will be booted successfully, but there will be no network
connectivity inside the VM.

In init systems like upstart this dependency between services can not
be expressed easily as the fact OVS started does not mean it has
finished its initialization and created all necessary bridges. We
would need an explicit notification sent by OVS to ensure all edge
cases are covered.

Retry an ovs vif port creation to give OVS some time to complete its
initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1532890

Change-Id: I5d3815c403098b2071da0ede21208ab7dc358edb

commit_message:
linux_net: retry ovs vif port creation

When a host is rebooted and resume_guests_state_on_host_boot is set
to True, it may happen that nova-compute starts before OVS finishes
initialization of all created bridges, and thus we'll see the
following error when creating an ovs vif port:

    ovs-vsctl: no bridge named br-int

An instance will be booted successfully, but there will be no network
connectivity inside the VM.

In init systems like upstart this dependency between services can not
be expressed easily as the fact OVS started does not mean it has
finished its initialization and created all necessary bridges. We
would need an explicit notification sent by OVS to ensure all edge
cases are covered.

Retry an ovs vif port creation to give OVS some time to complete its
initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1532890

Change-Id: I5d3815c403098b2071da0ede21208ab7dc358edb

commit_message:
Require privsep-based os-brick

This change moves to a version of os-brick sufficient to include the
rootwrap->privsep transition and removes the now-obsolete os-brick
rootwrap filters.

Change-Id: I2bfd002d5b619164ee5779063ba52076716de542
Depends-On: I0af542eba97d2f89b1c283bf1e1e985d9690f5de
Implements: blueprint privsep

"Use hotplug to add an network adapter to an instance"
"Detach an network adapter from an instance"

Should be:

"Detach a network adapter from an instance"

Totally 2 occurrences in /nova/compute/manager.py

commit_message:
Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first
job to check that recent changes for zuul-cloner work correctly.

Use constraints for cover environment. If this works successfully, the
other environments can be updated in followups.

Change-Id: I6069bee0a89d38f6a3ec57418e7bda9850dc6f64
(cherry picked from commit 1a95ac48b757a7d3050339fe72837f71f0351d74)

commit_message:
Pass request to v2 token authenticate

The v2 authenticate command is one of the last to still accept a context
dict because it has a lot of tie in with tests and notifications. Fix
all these so that authenticate can work with a request.

Change-Id: I07a2985fea7f71001c4a48d396167ea0e3a2a8f8

commit_message:
Prevent error when duplicate mapping is created

The mapping has unique constraint and creating a mapping with the same
local entity will fail. Creation of mapping with the same local entity
might happen because of race condition, that would happen if 2 processes
start mapping of the same local entity at the same time.

Return the existing public_id if creation failed due to duplicate.

Change-Id: Ic6e6ec9614e16a49c791dc6c06a4464d18be09be
Related-Bug: 1582585

added_lines: def test_create_duplicate_mapping(self): local_entity = { 'domain_id': self.domainA['id'], 'local_id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'entity_type': mapping.EntityType.USER} public_id1 = self.id_mapping_api.create_id_mapping(local_entity) # second call should be successful and return the same # public_id as above public_id2 = self.id_mapping_api.create_id_mapping(local_entity) self.assertEqual(public_id1, public_id2) # even if public_id was specified, it should not be used, # and still the same public_id should be returned public_id3 = self.id_mapping_api.create_id_mapping( local_entity, public_id=uuid.uuid4().hex) self.assertEqual(public_id1, public_id3)
